content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great job! Again, I cannot find a single improvement to suggest. This is a hard puzzle and I struggled with it. I kept going to back to the goal statement and reading the instructions over and over. As I sit here with a finished algorithm, I wonder why I made it as difficult as I did. The step-by-step algorithm now seem very clear. I believe this puzzle demonstrates how difficult it can be sometimes (for some of us) to translate clear instructions to code.

The test case design is well done and it helped me quite a bit to work my way to a full solution. When I failed a later test case, I almost wrote a question on the contribution page, but then I checked the goal statement one more time and my answer was right there.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: + Unique and original puzzle.
+ Clear statement.
+ Fun to solve.
+ Plenty of test cases, gradually implementing each rule.

~ Not convinced by Hard difficulty, but I'm probably biased because I got the right approach on my first solve (and difficulty can always be tweaked with success rate in mind).

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Reapproved

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: reapproved

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapproved

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

This seems excessively wordy.  Phrasing it as an "oracle" may add to the theming but to me at least it just comes off as frustrating to parse what the actual task is.  This is also not the description of a university math question asking for a proof,  I think hiding the definition of "s" within other wordy constraints of the problem adds to it feeling needlessly dense.  Also, I think some of the terminology should be limited.

Is this part really needed:

If ùíô = ùíö then ùìï(ùíô) = ùìï(ùíö). That is, the function is stable.

Do you have any references for this "stable" terminology? To me this could only vaguely make sense if the discussed equality was non-standard but I don¬¥t see it being the case.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: An interesting puzzle, I was struggling with it a few hours, but managed to solve in the end.  Statement and test cases seem to be thorough.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting and well-described problem. In my opinion, the difficulty level is appropriate.

Interesting problem that took me some time; I had difficulty with the last test (genius) because of the rule "At the point where the oracle has no other choice but to expose ùíî, fixing it to a single value, assign the first possible letter to that query."
I‚Äôll wait for more comments before approving. Thanks!
That's strange. This was the only test you had trouble with? In particular, the test titled coincidence was fine?

1. It's meant to establish that it really is a mathematical function, which in particular is something that could fail when you're trying to emulate it with a coded function.
2. It's a case that needs to be excluded from the "otherwise" clause.

The term "stable" is used e.g. in stable sorting, which maybe isn't directly applicable. I guess "single valued" would be more correct, since there are multi-valued functions like arg, but honestly I would find that more confusing. Another alternative is "deterministic", or maybe it would be better to say that the result or output is stable?

I see, probably not the problem for you then. The inspiration actually came from a university lecture, as Simon's Problem has no real world application, kind of like the Towers of Hanoi. Thanks for your feedback.
I do like the problem, I just think it could be phrased more succinctly and accessibly.  Granted, I don't know the best way to do that.

I'll grant you, the part that describes the oracle is longer than necessary. After Simon's problem is defined, the illustration isn't absolutely necessary either, but without it you'd have to read Wikipedia to put it all together. That problem is complicated enough that Wikipedia might be helpful even with. But then the oracle description takes two paragraphs, and is further illustrated in a third before giving the actual problem statement. The reason I'd rather not condense this, is that the puzzle isn't meant to say anywhere how it's to be solved, rather what must be achieved by a solution. Figuring out how to do that is what makes it a hard problem. Otherwise it would be medium with too many hints and spoilers, or literally easy if I spelled out the steps that need to be taken. So I'd rather have more example and illustration than less, for those who attempt it and then get stuck and need to come back for inspiration. This is why it seems to be defined in a circuitous manner. That's deliberate. The idea of the oracle isn't just a theme, it's a useful metaphor for how your code is meant to behave, rather than a direct implementation of a stepwise problem statement. Yes, oracles are common in theory such as proofs of computational complexity. This isn't that, it isn't a proof, but it's really close to one. There's a reason 'E' can't be assigned instead of 'A' again, and it's not obvious why unless you work out the logic.

I don't know any function, mathematical or not, that does not satisfies that, it seems tautological to me. 

Determinism is about calling the same function twice yielding different results, but we are not calling it twice. That wording seems to claim that there could be some functions where f(100) is different from itself, or if you want, that the result of the first call could be different to the result of the first call (sounds off no?).

But your point about the otherwise clause makes sense and with that in mind I see no issues now.

I guess what bothered me was the "stable" term implying that this property was relevant outside of the otherwise clause.

The address function does not satisfy this, if the equivalent strings have different memory addresses. A programming function with side effects does not satisfy this, for instance next. A nondeterministic function like ping doesn't either.

These make sense if you interpret ùìï(ùíô) = ùìï(ùíö) to mean two calls on ùìï. But to your point, there's not necessarily any reason to interpret it that way, if treating it as a math function where reflexivity is natural.

Black boxes have inputs and outputs. Instead of characterizing the function,  I've changed it to talk about output, as in the output of the black box. I too identify "stable" as an issue here. How does "consistent" sound?

The "coincidence" test was fine. My code was selecting the maximum among the remaining candidates to determine the letter to assign, instead of looking for the first valid letter. Only after careful reading, I did understand the issue, which I believe occurs only in that test.
I have modified the tests with this in mind. In particular, while the first test and validator will pass under that interpretation, the second will not. I've also added 2 more tests for good measure.
Luckily, my old code passes all new tests :-)
